page.title: 09TOURISM IN IGHTHAM (CONTD)
page.content: over-hang has been partly bricked up.The building is two storeys high but the centre part is the Hall and only one storey. The bay windows on the ground floor are notable with closely spaced mullions probably inserted in the{16th Century.}The front is much restored and the porch and oriel window with the ornamental barge boards are comparatively modern. The attic of the Hall is lit by two small{18th century}hipped dormers. The principal part of the Hall was used for general domestic assembly at meals, which from the cottage to the palace was denominated "The Hall". In the sleeping apartments above it is believed there were no fireplaces but one peculiarity which gave great height and air to the bed chambers was the lack of any lofts over them - the ceiling being placed against the
